designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) responds to a request by the Government of Bhutan to the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  additional  support  to  strengthen  the  development 
management capacity of the Ministry of Finance (MOF), and the government in general. The TA 
is  included  in  the  country  operations  business  plan,  2013–2015  for  Bhutan.1 Consultation 
missions were fielded, and the government and ADB reached an agreement on the impact, 
outcome,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost  and  financing  plan,  and  terms  of 
reference for consultants of the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  economy  has  performed  well  in  FY2001–FY2011  by  achieving  an  average 
economic growth rate of about 8%; this was higher than for any other South Asian economy. 
While growth is estimated to have moderated slightly to 8.3% in FY2011 from 9.3% in FY2010, 
it is forecast at 7.9% for FY2012 and 8.4% for FY2013 largely because of continued hydropower 
construction.3 In response to the high and sustained growth, Bhutan has been successful in 
reducing poverty. Based on the national poverty line, the incidence of poverty declined from 
about 32% in 2003 to about 23% in 2007. 
 
3.  Sustaining high economic growth remains a major challenge. Economic growth is largely 
financed by external aid. The fiscal deficit has been deteriorating; in FY2011 it was 4.7% of 
gross domestic product (GDP) because of rising capital expenditures reflecting hydropower 
construction and the increase of public servants pay in January 2011. The current account 
deficit has also been widening and is projected to be 20% of GDP in FY2012 and 24% in 
FY2013 (footnote 3). Bhutan’s external position with India has weakened greatly as power sales 
have reached generation capacity and import demand has accelerated because of the power 
construction programs and strong domestic economic growth. At the end of FY2011, Bhutan’s 
Indian rupee reserves amounted to about 1 week of imports, although convertible currency 
reserves were high at nearly $890 million, equivalent to about 9 months of total (essential and 
nonessential) imports.4 
 
4.  Recognizing  these  emerging  challenges,  the  government  through  its  Economic 
Development  Policy,  2010  aims to  achieve  economic  self-reliance  by  2020.5 MOF,  as the 
provider of stewardship for policy implementation, requires capacity building. For MOF to take 
on a stronger stewardship role in a dynamic macroeconomic context, it needs to adopt best 
practices pertaining to, among other things, fiscal policy and medium-term fiscal framework, 
budgeting and public expenditure management, taxation reforms and revenue forecasting, debt 
sustainability analysis, and government property management and public procurement reforms. 
ADB has a number of ongoing and forthcoming TA projects in Bhutan that aim to enhance 
MOF’s public financial management capacity.6 The proposed TA complements these efforts by

focusing  on,  among  other  things,  enhancing  the  understanding  of  macroeconomic  issues 
among  MOF  staff,  strengthening  MOF’s  capacity  in  macroeconomic  management,  and 
providing timely policy advice to address emerging issues faced by MOF. 
 
5.  As the nodal agency for ADB-funded projects, MOF plays a critical role in ensuring 
efficient programming as well as providing oversight of effective portfolio management. The 
2010  country  assistance  program  evaluation  rated  ADB  operations  in  Bhutan  successful. 7 
Bhutan achieved a 100% success rate for completed projects based on project completion 
reports issued in 2000–2011.8 Nevertheless, the evaluation highlighted that implementation 
efficiency,  although  still  above  the  ADB  average,  had  been  declining,  possibly  due  to the 
increasing size of projects and complexity of project design, frequent project design changes, 
and  increasing  work  volume  coupled  with  limited  capacity  of  local  contractors.  Given  the 
expected  increase  of  ADB  operations  in  Bhutan,  MOF’s  stewardship  role  will  need  to  be 
strengthened to enhance implementation efficiency and improve the development effectiveness 
of ADB support. 
 
6.  To  enhance  development  effectiveness, government  interventions  and  ADB  support 
must be more evidence-based. Data from the Third Bhutan Living Standards Survey, 2012 
under ongoing ADB TA, will be particularly useful in updating the country’s assessment of 
poverty and other development outcomes. 9 While Bhutan has made remarkable progress in 
reducing poverty and achieving the Millennium Development Goals, pockets of poverty remain 
and  inequality  is  persistently  high.  These  observations  underline  the  need  for  inclusive 
economic growth and development effectiveness. Rigorous analytical work will contribute to 
identifying development needs and formulating remedial actions to address them to sustain a 
high and inclusive growth trajectory.     
 
7.  The 2012 survey data together with data from the Second Bhutan Living Standards 
Survey, 2007 support evaluation of key achievements of the government’s Tenth Five Year 
Plan, 2008–2013 and the development impact of some of ADB’s key projects implemented in 
Bhutan. The socioeconomic assessment and impact evaluation studies under the TA will be 
highly relevant and useful for guiding the design of future interventions by the government, ADB, 
and development partners; and enhancing their continuous efforts to reduce poverty. 
 
8.  While ADB support for undertaking such assessments will be useful, ADB must support 
the government’s analytical capacity to formulate more evidence-based policies. Bhutan 2020: 
A Vision for Peace, Prosperity and Happiness highlights the need to strengthen government 
capacity to monitor and evaluate the development process and to undertake policy research on 
development issues;10 the proposed TA aims to support the identified needs. In addition, the 
government is elaborating a new economic paradigm based on well-being and happiness.11 The 
TA contributes to the new paradigm by responding to the government’s request for ADB support.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA impact will be improved socioeconomic management of the government for 
sustaining a high and inclusive growth trajectory. The outcome will be improved MOF and 
government capacity in development management.12 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  To achieve the envisaged impact and outcome, the TA comprises two major outputs: 
strengthened analytical skills for macroeconomic management and project implementation, and 
enhanced knowledge of socioeconomic assessment and impact evaluation studies. 
 
11.  Strengthened  analytical  skills  for  macroeconomic  management  and  project 
implementation.  Under  this  output,  in-country  training  seminars  and/or  workshops  will  be 
organized for MOF staff to enhance their economic management capacity. In-country training 
workshops on project implementation-related issues (including procurement, disbursement, and 
safeguards)  will  be  organized  for  officials from  MOF  and  other key  government  ministries 
implementing ADB-funded projects. To serve as training reference material, a compendium of 
guidelines on project implementation will be prepared and provided to the MOF and other 
government staff. In addition, at least one field trip will be conducted for the exchange of best 
practices and knowledge sharing with other developing member countries. The details of the 
topics to be taken up during the capacity-building activities will be identified and developed 
through coordination with MOF during TA implementation. The key criteria for the topic selection 
include the importance and urgency of the issues and challenges that could undermine MOF’s 
ability to undertake economic management and project implementation. Policy advice will be 
provided when and as requested by MOF to address emerging issues in a timely manner. The 
policy advice provided under this output will be published as an analytical report and/or policy 
briefs for wider dissemination.   
 
12.  Enhanced  knowledge  of  socioeconomic  assessment  and  impact  evaluation 
studies. The output will generate knowledge products, including (i) socioeconomic assessment 
and impact evaluation studies using data from the Third Bhutan Living Standards Survey,13 and 
(ii) analytical work supporting the government’s new economic paradigm. The socioeconomic 
assessment and impact evaluation studies are intended to assist the government and other key 
stakeholders  in  fine-tuning  policies  and  operations  for  better  development  management. 
Meanwhile,  the  analytical  work  for  the  government’s  new  economic  paradigm  will  directly 
contribute  to  the  body  of  knowledge  being  established  for  this  new  thrust,  supporting  the 
government’s  recent  initiatives  (footnote  11).  Inception  and  consultation  workshops  will  be 
organized for key stakeholders (including government ministries and agencies, development 
partners, and civil society) to ensure that the consultative approach is used for the conduct of 
the studies. Following the inception workshop, the topics to be covered will be decided by a 
project steering committee in coordination with the ADB TA team (para. 15). Study reports and 
policy briefs will be produced. Under this output, in-country training will be organized to enhance 
                                                
12 Development management in the TA refers to the coordination and management processes of development 
programs and projects, and the management of economic development of a country. 
13 The Third Bhutan Living Standard Survey was designed such that the impact evaluation of ADB-funded projects 
can be undertaken. The possibility of undertaking impact evaluation of other projects will be explored if the data

the analytical capacity of officials from key government ministries and agencies to formulate 
more evidence-based policies.  
 
13.  The main assumptions considered in the TA include (i) the external environment remains 
stable without any major shocks, (ii) the government uses analytical publications for policy 
formulation,  (iii)  officials  from  key  government  ministries  and  agencies  participate  in  TA 
activities, and (iv) required data and information are readily accessible. The main risk is that the 
government could be unable to retain trained officials in public service. ADB’s communities of 
practice, with their wide networks of experts on specific fields, will be consulted to ensure that 
qualified consultants are engaged for TA activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $735,000.00, of which (i) $475,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV); and (ii) $250,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Second Danish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance 
and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office 
space and facilities, counterpart staff, office supplies, domestic transportation, administrative 
and clerical support, and other in-kind contributions. The value of the government contribution is 
estimated to account for 1.4% of the total TA cost. The detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan is in Appendix 2. ADB’s TASF-IV and the Second Danish Cooperation Fund for Technical 
Assistance will jointly finance disbursements under the TA. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MOF will be the executing agency. MOF’s Department of Public Accounts (DPA) will be 
the implementing agency. The director of DPA will oversee TA implementation. ADB’s South 
Asia Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division will be responsible for overall 
supervision of the TA. A focal person, to be nominated from DPA, will  work with the TA 
consultants to facilitate timely and effective TA implementation. A steering committee will be 
established to ensure efficient and effective TA implementation. The DPA director will chair the 
committee, which will comprise senior officials from key government ministries and agencies, 
including the Gross National Happiness Commission and the National Statistics Bureau. The 
committee will meet every 4 months; representatives from the ADB TA team are to join the 
meetings onsite or through videoconference and/or teleconference, where possible.  
 
16.  The TA will require an estimated 29 person-months of consulting services (21 person-
months international and 8 person-months national). The actual requirements of each type of 
expertise and the length of their inputs will be identified during the implementation of individual 
studies. Given this limitation, the intermittent nature of assignments, and anticipated variety of 
expertise required, the TA will primarily meet its consulting requirements by recruiting experts 
on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). All procurement will be carried 
out in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented from November 2012 to November 2014. Implementation 
progress will be monitored through ADB’s TA review missions and regular consultations with the 
concerned  agencies  to  ensure  effective  implementation  as  well  as  early  identification  and

5 
resolution of emerging issues or delays. ADB will prepare the TA completion report to assess 
overall TA performance given the targeted pipeline of outputs. 
 
18.  Knowledge  products  generated  by  the  TA  will  be  disseminated  widely  through 
workshops and seminars, and ADB and government websites. Good practices and lessons from 
the  TA  will  be  shared  through  the  South  Asia  seminar  series  and  other  ADB  forums  as 
appropriate. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Second Danish Cooperation Fund for Technical Assistance, 
and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $475,000 on a grant basis, to 
the  Government  of  Bhutan  for  Enhancing  Development  Management  for  Sustainable  and 
Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consulting Services 
1.  Economic policy advisors (3 person-months, intermittent). The advisors will provide 
policy advice on issues identified by the Ministry of Finance as being of particular concern to the 
ministry. The advisors should have extensive work experience in economic policy making and 
development planning, preferably in capacity development; and have a good understanding of 
the identified issues. The advisors will 
(i)  review  trends  of  the  identified  issues  and  assess  the  relevant  policies  and 
strategies adopted by the government; 
(ii)  undertake a diagnostic analysis to identify underlying constraints;  
(iii)  formulate policy options to address the issues;  
(iv)  prepare training, seminar, and/or workshop materials;  
(v)  summarize the findings of the analysis and policy options in a report and/or policy 
briefs; and 
(vi)  design,  organize,  and  conduct  training,  seminars,  and/or  workshops  on  the 
identified issues. 
 
2.  Project management specialists (3 person-months, intermittent). The specialists will 
provide training, seminars, and/or workshops on project implementation-related issues. The 
specialists should have extensive expertise and experience in managing development projects, 
portfolio  management,  and  capacity  development;  and  preferably  be  familiar  with  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  guidelines  on  procurement,  disbursement,  and  project 
implementation. The specialists will 
(i)  upon consultation with the government, identify capacity development needs in 
areas related to project implementation and portfolio management;  
(ii)  prepare training, seminar, and/or workshop materials; and 
(iii)  design, organize, and conduct training, seminars, and/or workshops on project 
implementation-related issues. 
 
3.  Development economists (10 person-months, intermittent). The economists will play a 
leading role in undertaking socioeconomic assessment. They should have extensive expertise 
and  work  experience  in  economic  analyses,  and  preferably  in  capacity  development.  The 
economists  should  also  be  knowledgeable  on  the  four  dimensions  of  the  new  economic 
paradigm  advocated  by  the  government  (i.e.,  well-being  and  happiness,  ecological 
sustainability, fair distribution, and the efficient use of resources). The economists will 
(i)  facilitate the conduct of an inception workshop to discuss and identify key issues 
to be addressed in the socioeconomic assessment; 
(ii)  facilitate  the  formation  of  peer  groups,  drawing  membership  from  key 
government  ministries  and  agencies,  academic  and  research  institutions, 
development partners, and civil society organizations; 
(iii)  undertake a socioeconomic assessment and consolidate the findings in a draft 
report and/or policy briefs; 
(iv)  design, organize, and conduct training on socioeconomic assessment jointly with 
the impact evaluation specialist, and prepare training materials; 
(v)  facilitate  the  conduct  of  a  consultation  workshop,  and  prepare  and  make  a 
presentation summarizing the findings; 
(vi)  finalize  the  reports  and/or  policy  briefs  by  incorporating  the  comments  and 
feedback received at the consultation workshop; and 
(vii)  facilitate the conduct of a finalization and/or dissemination workshop.

evaluate the impact of selected ADB-funded projects, and should have extensive expertise and 
experience in impact evaluation of public interventions, and preferably in capacity development. 
The specialist will 
(i)  identify  and  select  the  projects  to  be  evaluated  in  consultation  with  the 
government and ADB; 
(ii)  conduct a desk review of project documents and prepare an inception report 
outlining the evaluation questions and evaluation methodology; 
(iii)  conduct empirical analyses of the impact of projects in collaboration with relevant 
government agencies; 
(iv)  prepare  a  final  report  with  details  of  impact  evaluation  studies,  highlighting 
lessons and recommendations for future operations; 
(v)  present summarized findings in a seminar and/or workshop; and 
(vi)  design,  organize,  and  conduct  training  on  impact  evaluation  jointly  with  the 
development economist, and prepare training materials. 
 
5.  Editor (2 person-months, intermittent). The editor will oversee the publication of the 
technical assistance (TA) outputs. The editor should have expertise in copyediting and desktop 
publishing,  and  preferably  have  extensive  experience  in  similar  assignments.  Under  the 
supervision of ADB, the editor will 
(i)  review and edit the draft reports, policy briefs, and any other knowledge products 
in a timely manner; 
(ii)  ensure that the reports adhere to publication guidelines specified in the ADB 
Handbook of Style and Usage and conform to high publication standards;1 
(iii)  oversee the layout of the knowledge products; and 
(iv)  oversee the publication of the knowledge products. 
 
B.  National Consulting Services 
6.  Sector specialists (3 person-months, intermittent). The specialists will mainly assist the 
economic policy advisors, and also be responsible for independent tasks. They should have a 
good understanding of the issues and be familiar with Bhutan’s country-specific context. The 
specialists will 
(i)  assemble relevant data and documentation; 
(ii)  assist the economic policy advisors in undertaking analytical work; 
(iii)  assist  the  economic  policy  advisors  in  preparing  study  reports  and/or  policy 
briefs; and 
(iv)  assist the economic policy advisors in the conduct of training, seminars, and/or 
workshops, and preparation of relevant materials. 
 
7.  Research  analysts  (5 person-months, intermittent).  The analysts will assist the TA 
team.  The  analysts  should  have  a  good  understanding  of  economics  and  have  sufficient 
experience in economic data analysis. The analysts will 
(i)  help assemble relevant data and documentation; 
(ii)  assist in undertaking analytical work; and 
(iii)  assist in preparing training, seminar, and/or workshop materials, presentations, 
and reports; and in publishing the TA knowledge products. 
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2011. Handbook of Style and Usage. Manila.
